content: In this section, we consider major broad economic trends. Economic trends inform our expectations of environmental impacts to be expected in the future.

sections.name: Technological Advancement
content: There is evidence that the pace of technological progress is slowing down. For example, Bloom et al. [bloom] find that research productivity is falling with semiconductors (Moore's law), agricultural yields, life expectancy, and general technological development. This means that more researchers--41 times more since the 1930s--are required over time to make the same gains. Similar results have been found with machine learning [models_hard], and in China and Germany [ch_ge_research] and Japan [japan_research].
One reason this is happening may be that, as knowledge advances, it becomes more difficult to operate at the frontier of knowledge [jones_ren].
Artificial intelligence may again accelerate the rate of advancement [ai_ideas].

sections.name: Economic Stagnation
content: Since the 1970s, economic growth and productivity growth in the United States and other countries has slowed, a trend that has been termed the Great Stagnation [great_stagnation]. Reasons for this may include a flatlining of the college premium, shrinking and aging of the population, and inequality [gordon_forecast]. In the United States, regulation has been estimated to reduce total factor productivy growth (the residual of economic growth after increased in labor and capital are removed) by two percentage points per year [regulation2p].
